10.32.text:
My name is James Evans, I'm a professor
at the University of Manchester and

15.52.text:
a visiting researcher here
at the University of Lund.

19.43.text:
My research focuses on
urban sustainability.

22.59.text:
Particularly, I'm interested in
how cities learn to become more

27.25.text:
sustainable through staging
experiments with new ways to develop.

36.40.text:
Sustainable cities provide people with
a high quality living environment

42.57.text:
without using huge amounts
of natural resources.

46.80.text:
Sustainability involves finding
ways to design cities that makes

51.40.text:
them good places to live,
as well as being more efficient.

56.31.text:
Luckily, there are lots
of ways to do this.

63.30.text:
Amsterdam is a great example
of a more sustainable city.

67.59.text:
In the 1970s, they decided to promote
cycling as the primary mode of transport in the city

73.21.text:
to deal with growing traffic
congestion and a spite of road deaths.

80.06.text:
Unlike motorized transport,
cycling doesn't require fossil fuel,

84.80.text:
it takes far up less space,
and improves people's health.

90.38.text:
As a result of this, the city can be less
spread out, the air quality is better,

96.59.text:
and the quality of life is improved
because the streets are safer for

100.80.text:
pedestrians to walk along and
for children to play in.

106.38.text:
Cycling is a great example of how
something that is more sustainable also

111.98.text:
produces more attractive places and a
better quality of life for the residents.

121.04.text:
In terms of energy in cities, reducing
reliance on the burning of fossil fuels is

126.84.text:
really the critical challenge for
sustainability.

131.08.text:
Cities are primarily trying to reduce
energy use in buildings and for transport

137.92.text:
by using new technologies and by changing
the ways in which people behave in cities.

144.97.text:
Cities are also becoming places that
produce their own renewable energy.

149.09.text:
For example, by encouraging home owners
to install solar panels on their roofs

154.69.text:
or subsidizing the use of renewable
technologies, like ground heat pumps.

163.88.text:
So, I think the key activities on
mobility in cities essentially involve

169.77.text:
getting people out of their cars by
promoting other forms of transport.

175.44.text:
This is things like active transport,
cycling, and walking.

180.54.text:
But also through investing in mass
transport, like light rail networks,

186.50.text:
bus networks, and so on,
which are more efficient than cars,

191.50.text:
in terms of taking up less space and
using less fuel per passenger mile.

201.40.text:
The thing that fascinates me in relation
to mobility is how the way in which a city is planned

207.30.text:
influences the ways in which
people have to use it and get around.

212.50.text: So in the USA, in the 1970s and

215.82.text:
the 1980s, cities really
sprawled across large areas and

220.69.text:
you had this spread of low density
suburban housing across really huge areas.

227.98.text:
This created a lower population density,
and huge distances.

233.62.text:
And one of the results of that was that
public transport - buses, railways, and so on -

241.11.text:
You just couldn't justify spending money
creating that infrastructure for so few people.

247.67.text: The result of this was that individually owned motor cars became the only way to get around.

256.45.text:
super commuters spending four hours
commuting each way to work, and so on.

263.12.text:
One of the best ways to make cities
more sustainable is to avoid that.

269.35.text:
To make sure that new urban developments
are relatively high density and through

274.78.text:
building cities like that, facilitating
more sustainable forms of mobility.

280.44.text:
Buildings use the majority of energy
in cities and this applies equally,

285.90.text:
whether we're in a cold climate or
in a hot climate.

290.15.text:
In cold climates, buildings use
a lot of energy for heating but

294.34.text:
in warmer climates, air conditioning
is also a major consumer of energy.

298.72.text:
So, a key priority for cities is to
encourage more energy efficient buildings.

305.32.text:
This can be done by requiring
new buildings to be designed in different ways,

311.36.text:
for example to make more use of passive
heating and cooling in cold climates.

317.08.text:
That might involve orienting buildings so
they capture more natural sunlight.

323.52.text:
Another issue is around retrofitting older
buildings that maybe aren't that efficient

330.32.text:
in terms of insulation with new technology
so that they meet higher standards.

339.93.text:
Government is what we often
think of when we think of more

347.00.text:
So, government involves
a body of people voting for

351.78.text: a politician who then makes laws and

355.04.text:
policies that we live by
until the next election.

359.61.text:
By contrast, governance involves
a greater range of people in

364.82.text:
the process of developing laws and
policies and making decisions.

370.43.text:
It recognizes that effective responses to
tricky challenges, like climate change,

376.98.text:
which we've never dealt with before,
require the input, opinions,

382.37.text:
and buy-in from a far wider range of
groups if they're going to be successful.

389.16.text:
In cities, this effectively means that any
groups who might be affected by a decision

396.00.text:
or a development should be involved
in all the stages of decision making.

405.20.text:
Making cities more sustainable
is crucially important.

410.15.text:
Cities produce three-quarters of
the world's greenhouse gas emissions.

414.61.text:
They're home to well over half
the world's population right now.

419.09.text: By the end of this century,

420.62.text:
that proportion will rise
to around three-quarters.

424.13.text:
That equates to about another
2.5 billion city dwellers,

428.96.text:
many of whom will be living
in new cities in Asia.

435.11.text:
So, in terms of protecting
the world's environment,

439.04.text:
limiting global warming to about 2
degrees C, decarbonizing our cities so

444.40.text:
that they are most sustainable is perhaps
the most critical challenge that we face.
